snippet.textDisplay:
I am prolly the odd one out but I enjoyed some things in Shadowlands.. it wasn't my top 3 by any standards but it wasn't terrible imo. ^.^; I loved the idea of the covenants. It was fun changing between them and getting different powers and seeing how they worked.. I liked that they each had their own little niche things.The raids also were enjoyable to me.. I raid at a mythic level and got CE in all but Castle cause diff guild. Obviously there are some fights I didn't enjoy but most were good. SOFO did seem like it should have been 2 raids and not 1. Shadowlands was also a great time for my class in M+. I was able to push for title which holds a sense of acomplishment for me.

The main thing I had a problem with was a lot of story elements. As I said ideas of covenants were cool but the story wasn't great in many areas. They did my girl Sylvanas dirty between BFA and SL.. did not like what they did to Arthas. Lotsa other things but I digress.  

As for the addon thing sorry but they should have made their own system alongside it. Getting rid of many is not the play but thats a different topic completly so I will hold my tongue here on this one. Only mentioned it because it was briefly brought up. 

I've played FF but more casually. I 100% agree most of the story is amazing. I haven't played the new expansion ppl complain about it yet though so we shall see.
FF housing upset me cause I felt beholden to never cancel my sub when I needed a break cause housing is hard to get. Then if it goes away you lose your hard work. I am loving WoW's housing so far and tbh the tools feel so much better to me. If I did ever take a break I can keep my hard work and easily get a house again and when I plop it down the work I put in won't vanish.

The main point I agree on is that competition is good. It makes games better and all in all it is usually a win for both communities. Without healthy competition companies get complacent.

snippet.textDisplay: I want to call DT 'FF14's Shadowlands' not because its as bad but because I want the devs to drastically make the appropriate changes just like WoW did. It didnt do WoW any good having BfA dwindling away their player base, it was bad but not bad enough. Shadowlands on the other hand? They were scrambling and panicking - and rightly so. I *want* the FF14 devs scrambling and panicking! I *want* them to take player feedback serious again, I *want* them to adjust. After turning my back to WoW, and like hell I'll ever return there (you might say, the Worldsoul Saga is good, but I know what "good" means in WoW terms, and I know they dont give a rat's a** about their lore, consistancy and story - 14 years playing WoW since BC have taught me that much: It'll always be "the rule of cool" for WoW), I want my game to be good again. I want there to be stakes, I want people to "die" so I can actually care to "protect" whats left.

Downgrade of quality was expected in DT. New story takes time to get up the speed. That said, i found very little enjoyable moments in DT main quest line and had feeling there could be certainly done more in many parts. But i think it began in EW, that against popular opinion, wasnt that good either.
Its hard to say why they arent capable creating darker, more adult expansions like HW or ShB. Various reasons come to mind, but i think they have decided to play it safe. 
Anyway. I think im done with XIV. It has nothing to do with DT really. With end of first story and change of atmosphere both in and out of the game, i was thinking about it before DT was even released.

snippet.textDisplay:
I feel WoW's 'resurgence' is more that WoW players are doing what they've always done and hopping back into their 10-15-20 year old accounts to continue as usual. As someone who tried to get into WoW fresh after getting pretty tired of FFXIV, WoW's new player experience is unbelievably bad.

I wanted to experience all of the content much like I could with FFXIV, see all those legendary raids and bosses and stories from years past that people love talking about - but to actually do that? I would have to make a dizzying number of alts and play in several different 'gamemodes' to actually experience it. I'd have to make an alt in classic, an alt in the 'remix', and then make several alts in retail to play through all the chromie-time modules.

And even then? A lot of that content is sparsely populated or straight up empty, and if you level up too quickly through chromie-time you just get... kicked out? Who designed this?

Apparently the latest expansion is trying to fix this but that isn't coming out for several months, and those solutions are only in piecemeal, at which point who knows where FFXIV will be?

snippet.textDisplay:
Dawntrail is shit.

Sorry, there is no sugarcoating it, I've been playing since 2013 and it's the first time I've walked away from the game.

To be fair, it wasn't just dawntrail, it was the post-patch content of endwalker that really started the downward spiral of the game.

The only saving grace of this expansion is the decision to stop catering combat content to the lowest denominators. The dungeons and raids are actually good. That's about it.

Since 2021 the game has become so infested with plugins, to the point where botting has become so easy and rampant that even raids became affected by the WoW mentality of 'DBM' gamers that can't play the game without their cheats.

If you don't use mods to alter your character, you're basically excluded from the entire RP side of the game as sex clubs and gooners took over the scene and don't care about your vanilla character.

snippet.textDisplay:
The wow of today isn't the wow of 2020 -- but i wouldn't be caught claiming that wow's story is good, so that's just out the door immediately. 

Wow housing being good -- I agree, but it also comes with its own problems like interesting bits of housing items being behind the cash shop (and we've all seen blizz start slow, then ramp up cash shop sets/items/pets/mounts to the point where regular content doesnt reward those anymore, or at least the best looking rewards are never from ingame content) 

The warband is a neat idea that brings what the fans wanted -- but with the typical "we'll do it our way" caveat, which blizzard brings into all  their positive changes. What I mean by this is you cannot send stuff you want. Only what blizzard allows you to. I can grind on my DRK for tokens and swap those tokens into current tier set pieces for another class completely, so when I want to swap to a new class, i'm fully decked out. In wow you can only transfer what amounts to a 'starting set' that gives you a boost. Everytime I want to try higher lvl m+ with another class, i still have to start from m2-m5 before getting where i'm comfortable. 

Now, one thing I'll give wow is the talents and abilities, because they've made significant improvements in merging gameplay and class fantasy. The classes feel superb to play and there's no longer a single viable talent path for each spec, while the others are never used. Credit where credit is due. 

Unfortunately, FFXIV going more than a bit under with Dawntrail is true; said expansion has brought a lot of annoyances with the game.  But the WoW bits are exaggerated and put in a more positive light than they are.
snippet.textOriginal:
The wow of today isn't the wow of 2020 -- but i wouldn't be caught claiming that wow's story is good, so that's just out the door immediately. 

Wow housing being good -- I agree, but it also comes with its own problems like interesting bits of housing items being behind the cash shop (and we've all seen blizz start slow, then ramp up cash shop sets/items/pets/mounts to the point where regular content doesnt reward those anymore, or at least the best looking rewards are never from ingame content) 

The warband is a neat idea that brings what the fans wanted -- but with the typical "we'll do it our way" caveat, which blizzard brings into all  their positive changes. What I mean by this is you cannot send stuff you want. Only what blizzard allows you to. I can grind on my DRK for tokens and swap those tokens into current tier set pieces for another class completely, so when I want to swap to a new class, i'm fully decked out. In wow you can only transfer what amounts to a 'starting set' that gives you a boost. Everytime I want to try higher lvl m+ with another class, i still have to start from m2-m5 before getting where i'm comfortable. 

Now, one thing I'll give wow is the talents and abilities, because they've made significant improvements in merging gameplay and class fantasy. The classes feel superb to play and there's no longer a single viable talent path for each spec, while the others are never used. Credit where credit is due. 

Unfortunately, FFXIV going more than a bit under with Dawntrail is true; said expansion has brought a lot of annoyances with the game.  But the WoW bits are exaggerated and put in a more positive light than they are.

snippet.textDisplay:
Having played both games, I genuinely enjoy WoW so much more these days. They've fixed a lot of the "creature comfort" issues that plagued the game before, and with housing they're quickly catching up to FF for the more casual audience. They also have way better events, like their anniversary and remix and collector's bounty etc. were all amazing, and all of that in a single year too.

 FF needs to take a serious look at its systems that it has left neglected for so many expansions, we need a reward structure overhaul and better content delivery in the patches. Better midcore content that isn't just coordinated dances that require 8-24 players to not screw up a single step. The game has finally started to take steps to addressing stuff like QOL, so hopefully we'll be seeing some facelifts soon to other systems.

snippet.textDisplay: This is the first time ever that I don't trust the future of FFXIV! I love WoW Midnight; I just did the Prologue & it is really good! I just wish it was longer! The rumors of Joshi P being burnt out & wanting to give up on FFXIV doesn't help! The other rumor is that FFXIV is going to cater to Eastern players & abandon the Western players! They have already adopted FFXIV mobile & it is thought that is what the PC game is going to turn into! FFXIV was my Main PC MMORPG but now that is Guild Wars 2, then WOW, & a low third is FFXIV! Dawntrail is a major failure! I just don't understand how they can go from epic Shadowbringers & Endwalker to the lame story of Dawntrail! I hope FFXIV gets better & Joshi P turns the game around, but I am no longer holding my breath on the game recovering!

snippet.textDisplay:
WoW and FF14 are completely different beasts with different audiences and issues.

WoW is saddled with a bloated, directionless team that decided to cut its own balls off circa 2021. I don't care what people say about Metzen being back will fix it all, the guy can only correct course so much when he has the rot of post-irony california liberal millennial writing teams incapable of actually producing anything that isn't self-referential or insisting upon itself. Midnight will either make or break them and you can bet Micro$oft is carefully checking every metric. If they don't see a turnabout in Midnight, The Last Titan WILL be the last expansion. Blizzard has never done an original idea of their own, their trick is pulling ideas and systems from other MMOs and putting their own spin on them, usually making them more accessible. What lets them down is the game has basically no narrative worth caring about. Characterisation is dogwater, you have inexplicable stories that not even the MCU could make worse. The soul of the game is quite literally being sucked out of it.

Square-Enix is set with a completely different set of problems. Their team can cook when they're given the direction. Dawntrail was basically made without oversight from Yoshi P (man had to basically split his team to get both that and FF16 finished and out). SE however is a Japanese company - which are NOTORIOUSLY slow to react to any sort of criticism beyond platitudes. The fact that he's actually come out and said recently that he knows there are problems suggests the higher ups in the company have shit the bed. Not that it won't make much difference unless they change core systems of the game. No one cares about classes being tuned (you don't see damage meters anyway so what's the point?) The UI, the inventory system, the transmog/glamor system, the housing system needs to be fixed. They've dropped feelers about saying yes they're addressing some of this but because SE works on basically production line philosophy anything already baked in won't be changed until the following expansion in a major way until then.

TL;DR? Square Enix has greater potential, greater spirit, but mechanically is being hamstrung. Even Dawntrail's story is better than anything Blizzard has churned out in the last 10 years.
Blizzard though? WoW is a slick game with rewarding and meaningful content loops, it has better class design (even if there is homogenization on a greater scale). But they've crippled their creative output. No one cares about anything but the pretty loot you get in your vault.

snippet.textDisplay: Why is nobody talking about the People that were there for the Story and the Emotional attachment to those Characters? Endwalker was a mistake for the narrative and it killed of Venat, our very Anker to this World. She was the Soul of this Game for Thousands of People. Yoshi Killed her off to end the initial Story of the WoL, which IMO is the biggest Mistake ever in any MMO. The impact her death had on the Game is something people dont take serious but I say it again. It was the Games single greatest Mistake to kill her. Yes you have people who dont give a sht about Story at all but knowing She was there somewhere to protect the WoL gave us the Player an actual purpose of being there to begin with. I might overreact here but I do believe it had a bigger impact on the playerbase than people realize.

To make a dramatic shift in FF14's design philosophy at this point will probably take at least one more crap expansion to figure out.

snippet.textDisplay:
The shame in Dawntrail is the "main draw" of a good story could have been so much better, but they just kept stepping in their own way with it.

Dawntrail also helped push me to a decision to make and that was, "FFXIV has ended for me". I played one of the best stories out there from before it re-started to it's conclusion. And it's likely going to remain in the top running for stories for me for the rest of my life. 

But the gameplay was never something I found all that great. FFXI's combat system was so much better and even the "modernized" version that game has still trumps the generic gameplay of FFXIV or WoW.

MMOs are a thing for the next generation to shape and run with, I had my fill. Now back to Warframe grinding that I keep dropping and picking up for almost a decade at this point.

Story there is as good as anything else out there and it's amusing how it can be told in an almost short-story format rather than a novel.

snippet.textDisplay:
The bottomline for either MMO to not fail and to be successful at this point ultimately comes down to this:  Acknowledgement and Support.

WoW's biggest failures isn't due to just one or more bad expansions, its was there arrogance of ignoring its fanbase by not acknowledging there was/is ever a problerm to begin with. Then not wanting to fix everything wrong and thus not supporting their game and letting it fail (that huge 1.4 year content drought in Shadowlands).  

As long as both devs are actively working to improve and adjust things by listening to their fanbase, they will do fine.  Online gaming as a whole requires this, and it ebbs and flows with ups and downs and the only way to move forward is to do those 2 critical things as it will always. So I think both will be fine long term.

snippet.textDisplay:
After thinking about it, I came to conclusion that this video is simply short sighted. You are looking at FFXIV through the perspective of WoW instead of looking at FFXIV from the perspective of FFXIV (ARR onwards).
The issue of story not landing is not the main issue why people compare the game to Shadowlands to try to make a point of how they feel about the game. However, this video mostly discusses story and does not go into the actual issues of the game that have compiled over a decade.

The game is extremely not alt friendly. The whole point of "play all jobs on one character" falls flat the moment you get into savage. I am a great healer and caster, but I can't gear both once the tier starts due to how gearing works - on average one job takes around 6-8 weeks to gear up, and if you are doing content in PF, it can take twice as long due to not getting loot and having to buy pieces, twines and shines with books. Tomes are timegated to 450 a week when we have 21 battle job, and frequently the jobs in the same gear category do not share gear either due to melds. Though for more casual people that is not an issue, it is something that cannot be just disregarded. This is especially important for things like preparing for ultimates on content. People have been asking to change this for multiple expansions to no avail.

Homogenisation is at its peak. It might be difficult to notice when you only dip into a few jobs, but once you've leveled them all, you notice how weird it is that you can take any tank and use exactly the same keybinds for not base of their kits: short mit, 40% mit, invuln, single target 123, some sort of resource spender, aoe 12 and aoe spender. Not even talking about role actions, as it's separate 7 identical buttons for all.
You might be more familiar with scholar, but have you tried playing sage? They have their own version of soil on exactly the same cooldown, same for whispering dawn, single target/aoe shields, aoe in melee, lustrate version etc. You can use baseline keybinds for both, and it's not even going into discussions that all healers have the same basic loop of 111111 with some dot in between.
Casters have been in a weird state for forever due to usually competing for one slot, and yet the role got a split in DT with "support casters" and "dps casters" that unless you are running double caster, one caster will just overshadow everything for an entire tier. Just look how PCT was dominating until 7.2 and since then BLM is the dominant one with the other casters barely seeing play.
Phys ranged are so unpopular that a lot of groups decide to just ignore the 1% and instead run two casters. Machinist has not had a tier where it was excellent and wanted over other phys ranged for literally multiple expansions.

8:00 "Corruptions in bfa being one of the most well received systems they ever done" 
Brother it seems like you ALSO have forgotten how bad that thing was.
We talking about random oneshots. People getting benched cause they werent lucky enough to get the right corruptions in 2 weeks.
DPS classes running out of mana cause they spammed too many abilities.
Semi-LITERALLY pay2win coming into the game,  where items with the proper corruptions got traded for millions of gold, while rank1 guilds deadass spammed servertransfer fees to collect those items.

Dont get me wrong, im a big wow degen who still plays through this day and has played through shadowlands and bfa. But that corruption system was one of the worst things they ever done. Fun, Sure. But boy i dont want that anywhere near the game anytime soon.

snippet.textDisplay:
As someone with over 20k hours of XIV, having been playing nearly a decade, it's REALLY interesting to me how you described Shadowlands.
Because to me, that is 1:1 COMPLETELY IDENTICAL to how I've been describing Shadowbringers since the very day launched. It had a great story, but it it removed nearly everything I loved about XIV all in one fell swoop.
I remember logging into the game on 5.0 patch day and feeling fucking devastated that the things that'd kept me logging in quite literally every day for years was COMPLETELY GONE with nothing to compensate for it.
Since then, I often go weeks if not months without even thinking about logging in, because the simple things that kept me playing are just gone now and something like 7 or so years later, they've done ABSOLUTELY NOTHING to contribute to restoring in some way, the gameplay experience that was taken away.

snippet.textDisplay:
As a late vanilla WoW player who played every expansion for at least some time except TWW I have not touched the game at all and never going back. I barely played Dragonflight and every expansion after Legion I played less and less as the game kept deteriorating. One thing WoW does extremely well is the gameplay, its very responsive and satisfying to engage with, but the game is a joke now. The storytelling has gotten significantly worse, there are multiple versions of classic, they don't know what to do anymore to gain and retain players, so they continue to pump the store full of junk to milk what players they do have. 

FFXIV has devs that don't hate their audience and are actually passionate about the game, Guild Wars 2 is great too and very unique in the MMO space while also not even charging for a sub. I personally ping pong between FFXIV and GW2 while trying the occasional new MMO. Blizzard needs to reboot WoW, badly.

snippet.textDisplay:
he main issue with Dawntrail is its story. The majority of players dropped out not because of the game design, but because of the story. The reason for the hate toward the expansion is simple: a game that was heralded as an amazing single-player experience through story alone is now offering a story that is really, really, really bad. Who would bother to play post-Endwalker? Word of mouth spread FAST, and to top it all off, even if the next expansion has a better or even a good story, who would want to put themselves through 100 hours of a horrible story just to get to the better part?

It‚Äôs a huge time investment. We all did that in A Realm Reborn, but we accepted it because it was giving world context and setting up the pieces, and we were promised several expansions of good story afterward. Dawntrail is a huge wall people need to get through, and I, for one, refuse to go through that. As you yourself said (paraphrasing) : ‚ÄòPlay other games if you don‚Äôt want to play FF.‚Äô We‚Äôre taking that to heart
snippet.textOriginal:
he main issue with Dawntrail is its story. The majority of players dropped out not because of the game design, but because of the story. The reason for the hate toward the expansion is simple: a game that was heralded as an amazing single-player experience through story alone is now offering a story that is really, really, really bad. Who would bother to play post-Endwalker? Word of mouth spread FAST, and to top it all off, even if the next expansion has a better or even a good story, who would want to put themselves through 100 hours of a horrible story just to get to the better part?

It‚Äôs a huge time investment. We all did that in A Realm Reborn, but we accepted it because it was giving world context and setting up the pieces, and we were promised several expansions of good story afterward. Dawntrail is a huge wall people need to get through, and I, for one, refuse to go through that. As you yourself said (paraphrasing) : ‚ÄòPlay other games if you don‚Äôt want to play FF.‚Äô We‚Äôre taking that to heart

snippet.textDisplay:
I've yet to see this mentioned anywhere: Netcode. It's plagued FFXIV for YEARS now. Between Rahban Savage/Pippin Extreme; the great 32-bit packet counter login queue reset kerfluffle; and the more recent datacenters come down whenever somebody looks in a mirror and calls out DDOS three times, it always seems like theres a consistent technical hurdle outside the players control they have to deal with just to PLAY the game.

New systems and content are GREAT; but the more and more players have to fight the above in order to enjoy the content, the less forgiving and tolerant they are...

snippet.textDisplay:
I‚Äôll add my two cents as someone who played World of Warcraft exclusively until around Final Fantasy XIV: Stormblood. Even now, I tend to jump into WoW (Retail) for a while, then drop out, while FFXIV remains my main game ‚Äî though I play it casually and don‚Äôt engage with the hardcore content. Personally, I much prefer playing WoW Classic in a hardcore style over Retail.
From a story and presentation standpoint, FFXIV completely outshines Blizzard in every respect. The Karesh storyline in WoW was good conceptually, but poorly presented. In FFXIV, patch 7.0 was weak in its first half, but the writing has been consistently strong since 7.2. Content‚Äëwise, Dawntrail has been my favorite expansion so far. Thanks to the evergreen nature of FFXIV, I even went back and completed Eureka during this expansion.
Jobs in FFXIV remain far more engaging than any Retail WoW class, which usually rely on simple 4‚Äì6 button rotations. Even Summoner ‚Äî often considered FFXIV‚Äôs most ‚ÄúWoW‚Äëlike‚Äù job ‚Äî has more complexity than any WoW class. Boss design in this expansion has been phenomenal, and the music, unsurprisingly, has been top‚Äëtier.
The one major drawback in FFXIV this expansion is the ‚ÄúMain Protagonist Syndrome.‚Äù The chosen character, Wuk Lamat, feels poorly written and comes across as a Mary Sue. On the other hand, Sphene has been very well received by the community. My server consistently has login queues, and in recent weeks I‚Äôve noticed a population increase, with many new players (‚Äúsprouts‚Äù) joining the game.
Meanwhile, WoW is also doing extremely well at the moment. I‚Äôd argue the two aren‚Äôt in direct competition, since the barrier to entry for FFXIV is much lower ‚Äî especially with its availability on both console and PC. To me, Dawntrail feels far more populated than the game was back during the downtime between patches in Stormblood.

snippet.textDisplay: If you remove class restrictions on transmog in wow, you lose all cosmetic sense of class idenity. Having a priest walk around in the T3 warrior set would look stupid as hell, and further destroy immersion in a fantasy world. Removing armour type restrictions would be a better move while keeping class specific restrictions would be more ideal, such as a priest wearing plate armour but cannot wear T3 warrior tier set gear would be a better solution without killing immersion.

snippet.textDisplay:
My main issue with DT‚Äôs story was they were clearly using the old playbook from ARR through Endwalker, where they had 10 years of content to pull from and call back to, things that make you go ‚Äúoh shit I forgot all about that!‚Äù. 

In Dawntrail the little flashback moments left me feeling like ‚Äúuh..yeah that happened like 2 quest turn ins ago? I just met this character 20 minutes ago and we‚Äôre doing a big emotional cash in?‚Äù It just kinda felt like they weren‚Äôt quite sure how to tackle a brand new story which made some, not all, of the moments fall a bit flat for me. 

The big examples for me were the old woman who helped raise Wuk‚ÄôLamat, meeting her in one zone and then time skip->she‚Äôs gone. 

And then all throughout Wuk‚ÄôLamats journey you were often getting those dramatic flashbacks that felt like ‚Äúoh oh remember when they said this thing??‚Äù And it was from damn near the quest right before it.

Overall I liked it, and some of the messages really do hit home for certain people with certain life experiences. It can sometimes be difficult to understand why something may be impactful if you yourself haven‚Äôt experienced it, so I try to be open minded and patient - which is the whole thing the story has been driving home for 10+ years.

snippet.textDisplay:
With all due respect, Mike, you don't play the game.  You have capped only a few jobs, you play for a few days after patch and then you leave to go play something else until the next patch.  You are everything Yoshi-P wants in an FF14 subscriber.  Many of us need more than that to justify a sub.  Especially if we're paying virtual rent for player housing.

You tried Occult Crescent and lasted only a little bit before you realized it wasn't Bozja and left when that's considered to be a really big part of the daily grind for people at cap.  You barely engage with many of the other systems outside of your house parties from your FC named after a dead meme from a deader mmo.

The problems that Dawntrail has aren't the same as Shadowlands.  But make no mistake, they are every bit as damaging to the playerbase and the drop in subs proves it.  There is a ton of dry rot underneath the surface that's festered for over 6 years now since Shadowbringers.  If you don't play the game much, which you don't, sure, you don't notice it.

I let both of my houses in prime locations get demolished and I feel absolutely nothing.  That says a lot considering the status symbol of those things.
This glazing definitely smacks of "Give me Interview time at Fanfest, Joshy-P!"

So as a dedicated 14 player I shouldn't worry because another MMO suffered a similar fate and recovered? How is that making us feel any better?
The difference is, WoW is thriving now and from the news I've heard, they're completely overhauling their systems from the ground up to entice new blood to join.
Dawntrail is what we 14 players are dealing with right now, this very moment. Let's also not forget that Activision Blizzard backed by Microsoft has orders of magnitude more budget and manpower than us.
Removing glamour restrictions ain't doing it. 14 needs to step up big time or else I don't see my favourite MMO being ranked 2nd in the genre much longer, with Runescape hot on our tails.

snippet.textDisplay:
While you make absolutely fair comments that a side of the community can be hostile, and downright dooming, the game had suffered from issues and problems that the most veteran playerbase has been calling since Heavensward if not longer, and, saying it in the kindest and not attacking way possible Mike, you simply are unaware of many of these issues. For better or for worse you ARE the target audience of the game, the one that mostly plays the MSQ, does the new content dropped, and a week later you are off playing some other game until the next content drop.

For example, and again, not trying to sound rude or elitist, one of the biggest complains of the game is the gearing up for Savage, which unless things have changed since I've last caught your stream, I've never seen you do since you started, while I've seen you do an expert roulette once in a while, you never capped your tomestones weekly, you never tried Savage and learned of the process of loot obtaining there. Then we got Job Design, people complaining how stale and samey they are, which again, what opinions can you form when you only got 3 jobs out of 21 jobs at 100?. While your opinion and expertise  as a content creator is welcomed, it doesn't holds weight against someone who has been around, and done, more of what this game has to offer.

So yeah, sorry if the community made you feel pressured by certain takes and opinions, some absolutely blown out of proportion, but do look at things from a bigger scope, people are not complaining because they want to see the game fail, they are complaining because they want to see the game BETTER, and the fact more and more people are opening their eyes that the game has indeed issues is a good thing, it's just up to the devs to parse up the good criticism over the "THIS SUCKS, THIS GAME IS DEAD, GGWP GO NEXT"

snippet.textDisplay: Calling Dawntrail the shadowlands of ffxiv is asinine. I think a more fair comparison would be calling it the cataclysm of ffxiv. They were both the start of something new, both were generally regarded as flops among their community, but still had some genuinely good stuff in them. And it's really the first time the communities have been VEHEMENTLY speaking out against them. Yes there's always been a loud minority of people opposed to certain changes in earlier expansions, or criticisms, but it's really those 2 expansions when a LARGE majority of the players were unhappy.
snippet.textOriginal: Calling Dawntrail the shadowlands of ffxiv is asinine. I think a more fair comparison would be calling it the cataclysm of ffxiv. They were both the start of something new, both were generally regarded as flops among their community, but still had some genuinely good stuff in them. And it's really the first time the communities have been VEHEMENTLY speaking out against them. Yes there's always been a loud minority of people opposed to certain changes in earlier expansions, or criticisms, but it's really those 2 expansions when a LARGE majority of the players were unhappy.

snippet.textDisplay:
Ffxiv's main problem isn't really even dawntrail at all. It‚Äôs stagnation. The devs have played it safe for too long through the years, unwilling to change core systems in meaningful ways. 

I've been playing since stormblood, and there's not much of a functional difference in the game since then. The game has been consistent but too consistent. It‚Äôs hard to maintain excitement for a game when you know what 95% of the content will be over the next two years, and can predict it's release times down to weeks.

The game just needs a massive shake up.

snippet.textDisplay:
Final Fantasy 14 is a game where any criticism that was brought up before Endwalker, was usually shot down by dismissive statements such as "it's not for you" or "it's ok to play other games." It was defended by players emotionally tied to a story that was built over years. Once Dawntrail came out and it was supposed to be a vacation, there wasn't anything that players could cling to in order to dismiss the same criticisms that were brought up alongside the new ones. 

Dawntrail's story was pretty generic overall, it had nothing else going for it and it even outright stated who the final villain was multiple times throughout the story. The battle content it brought in is some of the best overall, Square Enix just does these stupid implementations of otherwise fantastic ideas like how Occult Crescent worked with Forked Tower, one of their 48 player raids.

I never played WoW during Shadowlands so I'm missing some direct references, but both expansions don't seem to be remotely in the same wheelhouse.

yeah. no. Dawntrail is not like Shadowlands.
I went ahead and put some real sit down time with WoW in between Endwalker and Dawntrail, having never really done so before, and I would be lying if i said I didn't have some fun playing, even if I have zero intent of ever going back for various reasons.

Shadowlands is pure trash though. I tried sending a character through it, and I just couldn't, i went and did other things on other characters instead, had my fun there. Anyone calling Dawntrail 'Shadowlands of FF14' has no idea how insufferable that section of WoW really is, and while Dawntrail has issues a plenty, wouldn't say they are near as problematic as they where in Shadowlands.

snippet.textDisplay:
Preach, how much did Square Enix pay you to make a fluff video? This video only showed me that you can't be trusted and aren't worth subscribing to. There are so many things you stated that is just not accurate, it's not even funny. I've played both of these MMOs as well as others for many years. Played FFXIV since 1.0 Alpha and WoW since late vanilla/early TBC. The only thing I see from this is that you have no clue what you're talking about, especially when it comes to FF14. have you actively played ff14 for entire expansions or just check it for a week every patch? You're definitely not playing it on a consistent basis. You'd see everyone complaining they have nothing to do. If I were to say anything, it's that FFXIV is falling downhill faster than any MMO.  Also you may want to consider a few things, FFXIV never had as many subscribers as many claim SE never released official numbers but you can tell by their financial information, FFXIV is quickly approaching an all-time low.

1)  Nothing in FF14 is original, it's all stolen from elsewhere. Claiming it's a WoW thing to do is misleading as FFXIV has been doing it since Yoshida took over. The issue isn't copying  something, the issue rises from not putting their own unique spin on it, which SE did not.  Some examples include:
- The storytelling style and a lot of the plotlines come from FF11. SE's previous MMO which is far more open ended than FF14 which is far more restrictive by design. The only "original race" in ff14 is the Au'ra. The original races were all from FF11 though there were no highlanders and the Roegadyn were called Galka, had tails and they were considered male as they had no gender or reproductive organs of any kind. (Their lore is also far more interesting than any racial lore in FF14.)
- Housing came from LOTRO which released their housing in 2007. Right down to the exact number of small, medium and large houses per ward. It's also why FF14's housing is abysmal. SE just keeps it as a way to try to force people to stay subscribed out of fear of losing it and everything they put into it as if you don't claim the refund or items within 30 days after the house is demolished, you lose it all. 
- Performance as Bard? Also came from LOTRO.
-The very gameplay structure and loop, including the loot system is taken directly from earlier WoW eras. 
- The "Content is it's own reward" attitude for FFXIV not giving rewards for it's content is perhaps the one FFXIV thing that's exclusive to FFXIV. Wait, some rare FFXI stuff had it too. Seems to be a Square Enix problem.

The one thing FFXIV does do: Aggressively flooding it's cash shop like a free to play Korean MMO, but FFXIV has a sub fee you have to pay. And the fans are moronic enough to make excuses for them but criticize other games for having cash shops, including F2P ones. Completely ignoring that the FFXIV cash shop outfits end up costing the same as a F2P game's outfit when you add the fact you're also paying a sub fee for 14, but not for the F2P game. WoW's cash shop items are all account wide where as not a single one of FFXIV's outfits are.

2) Nothing in FF14 is "Evergreen" Roulettes and such only exist for incentive for people who are done everything to help others. The game would have been dead long before that if they didn't. I don't mind things like this being mentioned because this isn't a bad thing, but stop trying to sell it for something it is not. It's not "evergreen" That's misleading the content itself is worthless and obsolete outside of the roulette. It's only there so people don't have an even longer wait in queue because no one is doing obsolete content.

3) Nothing is account wide. Do you know what he term account-wide means? I'm guessing you don't. The vast majority of people who play FF14 play multiple characters. NOTHING is account wide, it's still all locked to your character. Outside of a few account wide cash shop mounts, you'll have to do and get everything again. and Most FF14 players do actively use alts due to a massive lack of meaningful content and people being bored out of their minds.

You stating this is misleading and you're doing it on purpose. Did SE pay you to do a fluff piece for them or do you just enjoy lying to people online?

The amount of stuff stated in this video is just downright incorrect or stated in a way that leaves it open for people to take what you say at face value rather than state the truth about FFXIV. 

The only thing this video showed me is you can't be trusted to give an accurate view of anything.

snippet.textDisplay:
this video coming out immediately after they released that the active player and subscription numbers are the lowest they've ever been. Endwalker was already a VERY low point in the game. the story ended in 6.0 and we got nearly 30 months of nothing but shallow solo content while players dropped off. People were constantly talking about how FF16 gimped Endwalker, that developing 16 made Endwalker bad and Dawntrail was supposed to be a good expansion that they'd make now that 16 was over. and it just wasn't it was more blandness. Nobody is playing the content you're talking about in this video. The devs themselves have said that the content you're talking about is the least interacted with content in the game's recent history.

Dawntrail is Shadowlands and if 8.0 comes out and its bad it will be a closure scenario for the game and this isn't doomposting its common sense. The game is coasting on being a barbie doll game with nothing else to do but dress up and people are bored. Because its been nothing but a Barbie doll game for 5 years now and the content cycle is only getting slower and more barren

What this video fails to understand is that if you were playing FF14 the past few years that you know the exact day The War Within came out even if you didn't play or know anything about WoW. Cause on that day, about a month after DT released, ff14 was a complete ghost town, and the majority of those people never logged back in

snippet.textDisplay:
WoW has three critical problems that will keep me away from it for the rest of time if that's what it takes:
- The WoW token
- Renown
- Zero community and zero interest from the developers to facilitate one

FFXIV has its own slew of problems, which face two critical problems and one PR one:
- The players will sabotage much needed changes if they believe it comes at "the cost of content", or otherwise do not care to consider _why_ something needs changing/adding
- The development time for much needed features. It takes at least 4 years depending on what it is, because the developers have trouble prioritizing seemingly small issues that have been left to fester for far too long. I completely forgot the 'raid planner' was coming, because it was announced over a YEAR ago. And that's for content that should be READY.
- Expansion advertisement is just riddled with semantic jebaits of disgusting proportions, Shadowbringers ("Warrior of Darkness") and Dawntrail ("battle the other scions") being massive offenders.

Before discussing the games, we need to discuss the developer's priorities and player bases' tunnel vision...

snippet.textDisplay: Last week a  whole party of my alliance raid in FFX14 called themselves the chicken squad and were all dressed as chocobo's, chickens and anything in between. Job indentity in armours is good, but with how many rediculous and equipable by all clothing sets there are it isn't suprising they should not restrict glamour between classes. Being a goober will always be possible, but most want their character to look cool. My main gripe with FF has always been that they have ignored so many small things over the years from old content to housing to glam that when Dawntrail turned out to be rather dissapointing nothing could distract from the dissatisfation that had built up. I hope they go a good direction and actually try to fix things, because excuses like spaghetti code can only get you so far before people are wondering if you even made a sincere effort.

snippet.textDisplay:
Dawntrail was always going to suck story wise. You can't compare a story ending expansion that covers the last 10 years to what is essentially a beach episode of anime expansion.

The dungeons and Trials have been pretty good so far, and a lot of people like the new raid series. [personally I think it was the worst raid series they've done but that's personal opinion].

The major issue stems from the battle classes not getting a proper revamp so it feels stale and the content cycle is far too slow. If they can get more good content out faster and give the jobs a decent tune up then they'll be absolutely fine.

DT has plenty of issues, but let's face it, most of those issues were in the game long before DT. This is the stuff older players have been complaining about for years but the newer players just didn't see it yet. Now the newer players have caught up and the game has been left hanging in a bad spot.

snippet.textDisplay:
As someone who extensively played both games, alternating basically since FFXIV inception in 1.0 - I can see the comparison to the Shadowlands, since from pov of someone who played this game for 10-12 years whiplash WAS this big,  I just think that people, in hindsight, forgot how flawed BfA was, that it kickstarted a lot of issues that were in the spotlight in Shadowlands(ramping up chores, borrowed power systems, sus content cadence, drop in story quality). And this is why I think DT is closer to Shadowlands than BFA, just for diffrent reasons, but i think there is an even better expac to compare Dawntrail to - Cataclysm. 
One thing i disagree with a lot of DT critics is that the issues started in DT. Far from it. Job design was consistent point of criticism basically since Summoner rework(Shb), so was lack of engaging content(starting with Bozja in Shb having weaker reception compared to Eureka as "easier" and "more dull" counterpart), semi-hc content also getting progressively easier(ie Extremes in EW) and the story started to weaken even in 13th shard saga(EW patch story). Oh, and also horrible netcode and tech debt, even though dev team claims there is no 1.0 residue left, even if we are pretty aware this is likely not true(showcased as recent as EW release queuing issues and constant vulnerability to ddos attacks and random routing switchups that are STILL present in the game and have been since ARR or lack of ability from the team to modernize Glamour system because of how they store item references in databases). It's just that MSQ still was the one big shield dev team could hide all of the issues behind and use to maintain good chunk of playerbase.  Once that was gone the flaws were in the spotlight and also content cadence changed giving players more times to brew with their thoughs, this is where a lot of people opted to grab pitchforks as they are obviously not happy with state of the game but too engaged in it to spend that energy somewhere else.
And we saw that in WoW already too - WotLK is generally beloved expansion, but it does have some decisions, that in hindsight contributed to design that players now question like group finder. It's just that the quality of experience we got greatly overshadowed those small grievances at the time. However, in Cataclysm Blizzard opted to go with even more 'risky' QoL and progression choices, and since expectations after Wrath were sky high and some things weren't received as well suddenly players have started feeling more impacted by those changes, but with story/content being less engaging they attributed those issues to specifically Cataclysm, even if in some cases that direction was simply continuation from previous expansions.
Do I think DT is death of the game? No. I personally unsubbed, I simply don't resonate with current story and ambience(I still think FF14 has superb fight design though, especially savage and above) but the game is far from bad still, especially for people who still have a lot of catching up in legacy/current content to do. However I do feel like current approach to design is flawed, the formula is safe and stale, the seem to be lack of trust in players to be able to digest complex ideas both in story and mechanics(kind of reminds me when Square attempted to dumb down FF for westerners with Mystic Quest, that one also wasnt received well btw) and the shielding that some content creators are doing towards the game will not help, will just hinder the experience even more.
We need to keep the pressure on the devs if we want the game(and through competition, the genre) to flourish, we just need to do it in responsible fashion.

snippet.textDisplay:
People really like to overhype how bad Dawntrail is, and Wuk Lamat just takes the brunt of it because she's the lead NPC of the story.

Fact is, though, every expansion had lead NPCs. Estinian and Aymeric in Heavensward, Lyse and Hien in Stormblood, Emet Selch in Shadowbringers, with Endwalker being the only one to really focus in on the player specifically.

The big problem with Dawntrail is the glacial pacing. Nothing really interesting happens until halfway through, the entire first half being a badly paced lore dump, with the second half stopping twice more for an hour+ each time to do more lore dumping. And the biggest problem with Wuk Lamat's actual character came right at the end when she jumped into the final boss fight to "save" the player, when lorewise the player character is basically a demi-god at this point and Wuk should have been vaporized instantly trying to interfere.

And the fixes of the complaints are already coming in through the post-game content. The raids are fantastic, the story refocused hard to put the player back in the spotlight, and even Wuk Lamat has been at least semi-permanently removed from the story, taking an injury that has left her barely able to walk unassisted for the foreseeable future, and said injury even came from a far lesser enemy than the final boss of the expansion she survived previously. And her fate is obviously to be what all other lead NPCs of the expansions and even the base game have been: Occasional cameos with little to no major plot relevance past their initial story. No, they're not going to kill her off, because they didn't kill Aymeric either, and he took a far worse injury in the post-Heavensward story.

And we already know the little post-game story in the patches is done as well, with the next patch to start the prologue for the next expansion, with already confirmed FF14's old reliable villains, the Ascians, are going to be back.

tl;dr version: Dawntrail is FF14's worst expansion, but it's still a hell of a lot better than a lot of other crap studios are churning out right now.

The big problem with Dawntrail is the glacial pacing. Nothing really interesting happens until halfway through, the entire first half being a badly paced lore dump, with the second half stopping twice more for an hour+ each time to do more lore dumping. And the biggest problem with Wuk Lamat's actual character came right at the end when she jumped into the final boss fight to "save" the player, when lorewise the player character is basically a demi-god at this point and Wuk should have been vaporized instantly trying to interfere.

And the fixes of the complaints are already coming in through the post-game content. The raids are fantastic, the story refocused hard to put the player back in the spotlight, and even Wuk Lamat has been at least semi-permanently removed from the story, taking an injury that has left her barely able to walk unassisted for the foreseeable future, and said injury even came from a far lesser enemy than the final boss of the expansion she survived previously. And her fate is obviously to be what all other lead NPCs of the expansions and even the base game have been: Occasional cameos with little to no major plot relevance past their initial story. No, they're not going to kill her off, because they didn't kill Aymeric either, and he took a far worse injury in the post-Heavensward story.

And we already know the little post-game story in the patches is done as well, with the next patch to start the prologue for the next expansion, with already confirmed FF14's old reliable villains, the Ascians, are going to be back.

tl;dr version: Dawntrail is FF14's worst expansion, but it's still a hell of a lot better than a lot of other crap studios are churning out right now.

snippet.textDisplay:
Preach raises good points but I still think the phrase is on point. No, dawntrail is nowhere NEAR as bad as shadowlands, but the parallels are undoubtedly there. The phrase comes about for how dawntrail is finally causing the giant japanese corpo who has changed nothing since stormblood to finally adapt and change, just like shadowlands really caused WoW to reconsider the way they do content. Like shadowlands, dawntrail has led to the same player exodus that we saw in shadowlands but in the reverse direction, something that Preach is somewhat downplaying here intentionally or (more likely) not. Player counts are now at stormblood levels(!). The image of YoshiP as someone who can do no wrong is shattered right now; even casuals on the most feel good reddit subs are floating the idea that he may want to step down for the sake of change and those threads aren't getting downvoted to hell and back like they would have been in SB/EW. Its difficult to emphasize how unlikely that situation would have been just a few years ago. That means its not just bittervets internet rage bait but real discontent among casuals, the MMOs most important population. This is, demonstrably, a shadowlands tier turning point for FF14 even if FF14 never dropped to shadowlands level bad. 

TL;DR: Preach makes good points but the analogy still holds.

My opinion on Dawntrail has always been:
The story was bad and should have focused on Krile and Koana.  Wuk Lamat should have been a side character if she existed at all.  A bad FFXIV story is still better than most other MMOs though.
The dungeons, trials, and raids are some of the best they have ever done.  The level of difficulty is almost perfect.
The character designs for the raids are great.
The zones are very well done, I especially like Heritage Found.
Overall, I am still enjoying the game and looking forward to 8.0.  I think the hate is mostly unwarranted.

snippet.textDisplay:
The issue for me will always be gameplay at this point and I encourage Mike to look into the "legacy of" every class gameplay throughout FFXIV's timeline to realise how much was lost. Even if the next part of the story turns out amazing, if they don't address the gameplay issues, I cannot see myself returning. Dawntrail's mediocre story isn't the reason people are losing interest, it simply failed to cover up how little engagement the current class gameplay requires. Stormblood started this design philosophy where it felt like the developers were saying: "you're going to play the way we want you to play or we will ensure you'll have less fun." And Shadowbringers basically cemented it.

WoW and FFXIV had to answer the same question: "what do we do when 80% of our playerbase sucks at playing the game?" 

Blizzard added the rotation helper and one button rotation as an optional feature. If you don't feel like learning, just use those tools and you'll do fine in most content. If you want to actually play your class and enjoy the intricacies, you can play normally. Also there's plenty of variety in specs which allows you to pick the level of engagement.

Meanwhile, Square-Enix simplified all class gameplay to the point where it might as well be a one-button rotation. Blizzard is also trying to streamline some jank from class gameplay in Midnight but so far they're actually selective about what counts as jank. To put it in comparison, Square-Enix removed any type of maintainable DoT, Random Proc, building / maintaining aggro or other unique mechanic from Stormblood all the way to Dawntrail, not because it counts as "jank", but because it can be "failed" by players. We're now at the point where classes that do still have a DoT like Gunbreaker can only use it after popping their damage buff to guarantee the snapshot.

Is it Shadowlands levels of bad? No, because they're not actively trying to go against what players want from the game. But they've been doubling down on a "lowest common denominator" game design philosophy that has been pushing a lot players away to go find something where the gameplay is actually engaging now that the story is no longer enough to serve as a motivator. And those players are spoiled for choice these days. 

I skip the story in WoW and enjoy the game just fine because the gameplay is stellar and engaging with a lot of variety. Content like Delves aren't hard but it's just fun to throw your class against them because the gameplay is fun as-is. Meanwhile i cannot see myself going through the same dungeon hallway layout again for an entire FFXIV expansion pack where I'm pressing 1-2-3 over and over and pop one ability ever minute or so.

snippet.textDisplay:
The two things I honestly feel like FFXIV needs to do, is completely redo their UI from the ground up to look less ancient and cluttered, and un-fuck their netcode so that boss fights aren't built around snapshotting. The latter in particular I think is very important, because the inability to have "real time" action restricts how they can design their fights.

They also need to make classes less homogenous. It's been a little while now since I booted up FFXIV, but last time I did custom "builds" and stuff still really weren't a thing. There was one clear path for BiS gear, and a rotation to learn, and that was kinda it. They need to shake that shit up. Introduce specializations. Make gear more interesting. I get that the homogeneity makes for tighter tuning in fights, but I'd take some looseness there if it meant more joy from experimenting in how you fundamentally play the game.

I also feel like S-E really just need to invest more resources and people into FFXIV overall. More unique cutscenes with custom rigged animations instead of cycling through emotes. More voice acting. More unique music. If you're competing for the crown, then act like it Squre-Enix.

snippet.textDisplay:
I Stopped playing at the start of Endwalker, bcs classes are boring and raids/trials are boring.
And I was playing even before WoW was "bad".

It is alway the same but with different coat of paint.
As main healer FFXIV healers are most boring designed class I ever played in any MMO. Every healer in FFXIV is same with same buttons on same CDs. Their little gimmics bassicaly dont change that much you are still presing 1 refreshing your dot and your AOE healing CD. DPS are behind memorization of your rotation with 0 player skill behind it.

Raids are also largely scripted. Whole game is like playing simmons says. Patter green -> solution green. There is no player expresion, you dont need that one or few good players who do this specific mechanic, bcs everyone is playing bassicaly same role in raid.

When Dawtrail released I was not interested, no class or raid/trial changes, story in boring world and when I looked at the story even Fantasy from Final Fantasy is gone. Boring empty high tech city. Modern glamour after modern glamour.

I dont know If I ever come back, because I dont want to spent hours playing through endwalker post game and whole Dawntrail just to get in maybe good bits again in upcoming expansion. It is way too long and I am not interested.

Using every armor type is great but glamour system by default sucks. Limited number of slot for how many pieces you can have, Even in Shadowbringers I had full wardrobe and was buying retiners just to have space where I can store some glamours I dont use now. And complains about store in WoW when FFXIV always had best and most used glamours on their store? What? When you cant even change your character without paying for fantasia, good luck when you fucked up and pick ungly nose but you didnt noticed.

Overall they can add QoL how much they want but until they fix the classes and make fights engaging I would not even consider coming back.

snippet.textDisplay:
If your premise is that DT has not been an absolute disaster for FFXIV, then I respectfully disagree. Not only is its MSQ terribly boring but the vast majority if not the totality of its new characters are at best boring and at worst utterly obnoxious stereotypes. So far even the XI collab is feeling lazily written with a poor story and nothing but base level fanservice. Meanwhile the tournament arc of the normal raids is barely interesting and has already been done much better by Omega. Really the only content I can maintain any interest in is what's *not* directly related to Tural: Occult Crescent has ARR lore, Cosmic Exploration keeps us in touch with the adorable Loporrits, and Pilgrim's Traverse lets us revisit the First as well as gives us more fae lore. For all that people, yourself included, want to claim that DT is at least better than SB, you could not even begin to compare the two. SB had an energy to it, good content, and great lore on all sides. DT meanwhile had characters that were not the least bit engaging on both sides.

I'm of the opinion that the Endless will be XIV's downfall if they keep exploring the concept. We need to move on from it to better areas and storylines: Corvos, Meracydia, Aerslaent, the Thirteenth, and any other areas mentioned by the minor Scions if you spoke to them before finishing the last 6.0 quest. This game has too much going for it to be bogged down by one bad expansion but we need to leave Tural behind for good.

You don't need to be outraged in order to acknowledge the massive drop in quality of pretty much all main DT content, in particular the MSQ. You certainly don't need other people to tell you how to feel or what to say about it either. But let's be real here: just because DT isn't as bad as your Shadowlands does not make it any less of a disaster for XIV. I agree with you that we will move on and recover from this, but that won't make DT any better in retrospect.

snippet.textDisplay: As someone who loved Dawntrail maybe more than even Shadowbringers or Endwalker, I am simultaneously confused and thankful that people hate on it. I really do hope that all the loud angry people get them to mix things up more with the next expansion, because the further this cycle of samey content goes on, the less and less I find myself playing outside of new story content.

snippet.textDisplay:
The MMO genre is a very ‚Äúwhat have you done for me lately‚Äù genre but I‚Äôve been in it for 15 years and I don‚Äôt forget so easily. Dawntrail wasn‚Äôt my favorite expansion. I liked the back half of it a little more, and the patch series has been pretty good. But I didn‚Äôt love it. Still, it didn‚Äôt magically undo the love I have for the game from the moments that made me cry in Shadowbringers, or the moments that made me smile through tears in Endwalker. Those are still very special to me. DT takes places on a new continent and it being boring doesn‚Äôt really ruin anything for me. I like the cultures, because the cultures weren‚Äôt the story. They were just part of it at points, so I‚Äôm not left with any lasting disdain

Shadowlands? Ho boy. I was there for BFA, Shadowlands, and Dragonflight, and I hated all 3 of them. I hated them *so* much that my love of Night Elves, of the lore of Warcraft, was *broken*. I don‚Äôt care how much content they‚Äôre putting out, I don‚Äôt want to be in Azeroth anymore. I‚Äôm not interested in being there. I don‚Äôt care about its races any longer. And all of that because that trifecta of expansions severed my connection. So, I gotta agree. I really don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs the same. I‚Äôm sure some people will come along and swear DT ate their cat or something but I‚Äôm talking about 3 expansions here. That‚Äôs like 8 years man. For 8 years I‚Äôve been completely over the WoW storyline as a direct result of its expansions continuing that storyline. I was an Anduin fan because I loved him in the novels, and Shadowlands punished me for that every chance it got. Now he‚Äôs back and being all emo about that awful BS he went through in that throwaway plot? When he was made the Temu Lich King for like 5 minutes?

snippet.textDisplay:
You'll never hear me praise DT's main story for 7.0. So many of it's moments didn't land for me. I really didn't like how they split dialogue between the characters. I felt that a lot of it's plot was very dumb should have been handled differently. You should not ever make the player feel their character is almost usless and unimportant in story this long. That's how you get people to quit.

 However, that does not mean I hate DT. Bosses, new jobs, environment design, all the new music(expect Smile), and the patches around 7.2-7.3, a ton of the extra content like Nraids, Araids, Chaotic, or Deep Dungeon have all been amazing. Don't get me started on Mandeville and Cornservant quests, peak gaming right there. 

DT is Stromblood 2. A not very highly praised story, but a lot of other parts were really well loved. Though I think 7.0 story was honestly far worse then Stromblood. I've played Stromblood twice now and honestly it's a good story, it's just not Shadowbringers good. They also managed to make the WoL not the main character but still feel important. Many of the bosses and smaller story beats were focused on the WoL. Which I felt literally none of that in 7.0. 7.2-3 yeah that is back, but not 7.0. You get one moment at the end, but 40 hours in is a bit late.

snippet.textDisplay:
Thank you for the video @Preachgaming! About time someone said it loud that DT is no where NEAR as bad as SL.
FF14 Dawntrail story had issues, everyone can agree to that, but it cannot be overstated that the amount of hatred and vitriol the game has gotten due to made up political bigotry and griefter engagement has done some damage to the reputation of DT. I've seen many content creators who have spoken about FFXIV giving legitimate criticisms get harassed because they weren't "harsh" enough.

The reality of it all is that Despite its setbacks, Dawntrail, similar to BFA, its still a good expansion with many welcomed changes and tremendous QoL improvements. 
But Like you said the devs are taking up some of these issues and pushing forward to further improve the game. They have time and time again proven that if the game is going into a direction that people aren't having fun with, they will do what is needed to fix the problems. I believe if continue  they focus to improve and fix years old issues and add even more content that is unique, like deep dungeon, that the game will continue to flourish. We still have one big patch before the expansion, thats 7.5 and I would not be surprised if they made housing changes that matches that of WoW, plus the addition of Beast Master in 7.5. 

I think both games need each other to continue to succeed and tribalism is bullshit.

snippet.textDisplay:
I think the WoW tmog restriction is good/ fine because its one of those last remnants of class identity/ rpg choice in the modern game. When you look at a paladin or a warlock, they have a certain look to them, and its quite consistent. It makes the characters in the world more readable and believable, compared to something else where you see someone in full plate or robes and literally could not guess, because the looks became homogeneous. From BfA-Shadowlands they even had the armor type specific tier sets, remember those? and remember how buns they were cause there was no class identity in the game anymore and a lot of ppl looked the same? yeah....

I do wish the stupid shop skins werent a thing too, but unfortunately I do not run blizzard so I have no input. Im just glad that the universal tmogs are very few, its probably just a handful, not that big of a deal.

snippet.textDisplay:
Great video !

I also believe comparing DT and Shadowlands is absurd, Dawntrail mainly exacerbated flaws FFXIV already had and the story looks like a child's fanfic. Aside from these, as you said, there are some excellent contents and the PvE side of the game is bright, although one would argue there is far less content and far lss variety than in WoW.
FFXIV allowing every glamour on every character is a fine exemple of them offering what they're good at ; on the other end, WoW offers a housing that SE could never dream of.

In my opinion, FFXIV as many more glaring issues to tackle (taking half a year for some contents like alliance raids that take an hour to get bored with is insulting for instance) and I'm not giving it a chance if they can't strengthen their main quality (its story), but the game very much is worth it. They also announced bigger changes so it would be very unwise to consider them lost.

snippet.textDisplay:
Setting aside problems with the story that have been well hashed out, I don't think Dawntrail broke cleanly enough with the previous story. It was time for the WoL to go somewhere and meet completely new people rather than having the whole same crew bouncing along.

But also, I tried logging back into FFxiv during a lull before the most recent WoW patch, and the things to do were just really, really uninspiring. I just don't want to spend time in that story and everything that's going on there. It's unfun! I don't have a ton of interest in running their LFR analog for a gear set that doesn't matter. It's just dull.

To each, their own, but yeah. FFxiv really, really needs to change things up.

snippet.textDisplay:
I appreciate that you try to look at things more fairly, but I think this is being way too generous to FF14. I'm not talking about MSQ at all, there are many more issues with the game that have compounded over the years that they've ignored which has put them in a tough spot once that veil was lifted from the eyes of the playerbase recently. I see the title has changed, but if I had to make a comparison to a WoW expansion, this would be like Warlords of Draenor - the "raid or die" expansion. It's not really as bad as that because an FF14 expansion has 5 major patches in an expansion after the launch patch, so there will be more content than WoD regardless which had 1 patch (not counting 6.1). But it's the same kind of deal, if you're a veteran casual player who is playing patch-by-patch, there's barely anything to do. If you're a hardcore player, the devs have given you a massive amount of very difficult raid fights to do. Which is nonsensical in the first place since the hardcore crowd is around 10% or so of the playerbase. This game is not in a good state, the latest player numbers have dropped substantially, and they've ended up putting a lot of pressure on themselves for 8.0 by putting aside issues like the homogenized job design that we've had since Shadowbringers for years, while not delivering on the content side for the majority of the playerbase either, and letting issues like spaghetti code, the repetitive formula, longer patches with no real repeatable content and lack of innovation fester over the years as well.

There is a big frustration in the playerbase these days from the developers ignoring feedback for years. You know the glamour unlock that you were praising in the video? Yoshi-P said multiple times before, even as recent as this expansion that he didn't want to unlock any glamour restrictions because he didn't like the idea of Black Mage wearing tank armor. They finally budged on it when they kept losing subscriptions. 10 Years to add chat bubbles and other basic addons is not something to praise either. A lot of feedback these days ends up becoming uncivil because of the frustration of the developers not listening. Sure, we get live letters, but they don't ever talk to us like they're actually listening anymore. What did Yoshi-P say about the Forked Tower issue? It was due to cost that we didn't get a normal mode. That is not due to cost, it's bad decision making to make a harder version only in an expansion that was already devoid of casual content by then. What have the developers said about job homogenization and over-simplification since Shadowbringers? Nothing - too bad if you want classes with more depth than just dealing raw damage. Instead, they doubled down on it in Endwalker, and then again in Dawntrail, while Yoshi-P tells everyone to wait until 8.0, which was 2.5-3 years away at that point, for more meaningful job changes that aren't just "Deals potency to enemy". The Q&A they did in the 7.2 live letter was refreshing actually because they really don't ever talk to the playerbase about their questions and concerns, I wish they'd keep doing that or send surveys, something to be more in touch with the game and playerbase who want to play the game but have lost reasons to play.

CBU3 has grown complacent in recent years from the success of Shadowbringers and the drowning out of constructive criticisms from the community, and I hope they can make big improvements to the game in 8.0. They know something is wrong, because Yoshida himself said they want to do some sort of "rebirth", and SQEX's Kiryu was even told directly by a shareholder about the decline in quality and players in Dawntrail, to which he responded that he was aware of it. I see some comments on this video of people being very defensive of the game, which the FF14 community is kind of notorious for, and that doesn't help anything. Players like that who want to drown out all negative feedback and criticisms are hurting the game more than anyone. It's important to give constructive feedback where it's due, and FF14 has a lot that it has to work on - the dwindling sub numbers and higher levels of negativity everywhere you look are proof of that.
snippet.textOriginal:
I appreciate that you try to look at things more fairly, but I think this is being way too generous to FF14. I'm not talking about MSQ at all, there are many more issues with the game that have compounded over the years that they've ignored which has put them in a tough spot once that veil was lifted from the eyes of the playerbase recently. I see the title has changed, but if I had to make a comparison to a WoW expansion, this would be like Warlords of Draenor - the "raid or die" expansion. It's not really as bad as that because an FF14 expansion has 5 major patches in an expansion after the launch patch, so there will be more content than WoD regardless which had 1 patch (not counting 6.1). snippet.textDisplay:
The thing is with Dawntrail, is that in fact it needed to scale down the story so it could be eventually built up again to a climax, but Dawntrail did the exact opposite. The story and characters were immediately less interesting and by the end you were fighting another threat to the 14 worlds, in a multi-universe ending threat, that wasn't that much different from a marvel movie, and their crap movies at that.

I don't play wow, so can't really say what that compares to, but Dawntrail made me stop playing FF14. The drop in quality was so evident that there's no positives to wait for in the future, and as the story I cared about already ended, in a satisfying ending too, sticking around for something less would feel like a waste of time. Like watching a TV series that returns after 10 years and the new episodes just aren't as good as the previous seasons.

snippet.textDisplay:
The thing about the division between the Scions...the way they presented it, the "who will become your allies and who will become your rivals" in the bid for the throne, it never seemed to me like it was going to be a big deal. Though that may have come from having watched similar "what do they mean by that?" reactions to the vague hint statements they'd made in past expansions that were never, ever as big as the speculation made them out to be. Being there during Stormblood during the lead-up to Shadowbringers, there was more speculation about being the Warrior of Darkness and what that meant. Ultimately, it was still us being a hero but in a world where an over abundance of Light was an issue, but much of the speculation was centered around the WoL possibly having to turn "dark" or go antihero to achieve their goals. Endwalker kind of sidestepped the issue...because they were hiding a lot more of the story details than usual. And then Dawntrail was back to the usual "take this thing and speculate about it and expect it to be this big significant focus of the story and...it usually isn't, because they tend not to talk about the biggest things in the Live Letters and Fanfests, as it turns out.

Basically, if they highlight it directly, it's generally not going to be the biggest thing waiting for you. At least that's been the pattern so far, and something I try to keep in mind when they talk story details ahead of time.

snippet.textDisplay: I play games mostly for the gameplay. I played through the entirety of 14's msq because I wanted to give it a shot, and didnt want to feel like I was missing out. I hated most of 14's story, like I was engaged with at times during stormblood and shadowbringers, but over all it was a boring slog. So all the backlash behind dawntrails msq to me feels a little weird because from my perspective dawntrails story isnt that much worse than the other msqs from previous expansions. The community at large hates wuk lamat, I actually lile her. So yeah dawntrails msq was a long tedium, but the msq in 14, is always a long tedium of endless exposition about nonsense. If it were up to me the msq would be more dungeons and trials, less yapping. But I loved the normal\Savage raids, I liked some of the dungeons, I enjoyed occult cresecent for the first week until I did everything, been enjoying deep dungeon, I loved chaotic raid, treasure maps, trials, alliance raids. Like the game part of dawntrail to me is great, which is what I care about. If it were up to me like Id be cool if the msq was removed entirely from the game so I could just play the fun parts of the game. But for people who love the story many of them see the dawntrail msq as a big letdown. But from my perspective like its still like a million times better than arr msq, which is why I basically mever play my alts because going through the slog that is arr msq is a nightmare.
