snippet.textDisplay:
As someone who played during BFA, I have to disagree with this assessment. You can say many things about BFA, it surely was not the best expansion, but I don't believe it should be regarded as equal to Dawntrail for XIV. When I logged in during BFA, I never felt like I had literally NOTHING to do. Even between patches, there was always something to do. The player count was on a stable decline, at least until Classic WoW launched and fragmented the playerbase. There was SOMETHING to do, there were people to do that "something" with.

I believe it was completely missed a major factor in why people are leaving FFXIV behind. Both the Length of time between patches, and the amount of content, and in a lot of cases quality of content in patches is absolutely abysmal. Honestly why should any of us stay subscribed to the game after playing the patch and doing literally all of the new content that matters in one week? There is literally 5 months of NOTHING between patches and it is culling off the playerbase like you could never imagine. The story can be bad, but if the majority of people are standing around with nothing they care to do, good luck patching together a broken community. One other thing I should add is that XIV had the chance to LEARN from WoW, and Blizzards failure. Blizzard was arrogant, they ignored the advice and feedback of their playerbase. Yoshida and his team have fallen into exactly the same trap of ignoring community feedback. This is why jobs have all become mindless despite protests (especially from healers) going on since Shadowbringers, to which he directly told them to "Go play Ultimate". I would not assign brownie points to FFXIV for adding basic quality of life features that had to be modded into the game because they didn't want to spend a trivial amount of their budget incorporating them into the game. (Chat bubbles takes 10 years to add to the game? How about gizmo's to place furnishing in our houses better? The UI is literally so bad it contributed to the creation of DISCORD.)

The amount of player loss, and reputational damage to the game is on par with Shadowbringers, I hate to say it. The community, (Or former community at this point.) is not going to come back. Dawntrail is a permanent smear on the games legacy and reputation.

snippet.textDisplay:
Wholeheartedly agree.  Competition = New and innovative content.  The problem WoW had for so long was that they were officially the MMO juggernaut for the LONGEST TIME.  Hardly any other MMORPG could match or even excel where they were and that alone led to years of stagnation.  FF14 was the kick in the face Blizzard needed and while I don't see myself going back any time soon (got pretty screwed over with with Warlords of Draenor.  Not impossible but not likely.) its good to see Blizzard is thinking more outside the box.  Now this alone will make Square Enix go, "okay we're starting to stagnate to so time to try a different approach."
THAT IS REALLY GOOD FOR THE MARKET AND THE CONSUMER.

THAT IS REALLY GOOD FOR THE MARKET AND THE CONSUMER.

snippet.textDisplay:
I started WoW in Shadowlands. I think it's an expansion that benefits from not being current content. The annoyances aren't as -- well, annoying, when they're not forcing you to do Torgast and WQs like a second job as part of player progression. I find myself dipping back into the expansion here and there to get Covenant transmogs and mounts. You get more out of it when you stop and smell the roses, and just pick the bits out of it you like, instead of needing to grind grind grind. There's the "evergreen content" you're mentioning. Plus the four main environments for the expansion are so sick, and sorta shit on anything XIV has to offer. As a player who genuinely likes to explore and kinda breathe in the environments, my opinion is that Shadowlands is a fun time if you choose to overlook the issues it had back in 2020.

If they ever brought out a Shadowlands Remix, I'd rather play that than XIV, to be completely honest. XIV is a game where I've had five or six failed attempts to get into it. Not enough there to keep me wanting to log in.

snippet.textDisplay:
Dawntrail is more enjoyable than Endwalker for me. Endwalker was truly the worst. The content is just plain better in Dawntrail (especially the normal not-savage content, it's A LOT better.)

Sadly, that's not good enough to make up for the game's systemic issues, like:
- An MSQ that keeps getting longer every patch and every expansion, discouraging new players
- Unrestricted DC travel has destroyed the community
- Job design issues (homogenization, tank healing, some jobs like SCH have no identity, little opportunities for skill expression, etc.)
- Cheats, addons, plugons, etc.
- Clunky UI limitations (why can't I remove a materia while talking to a vendor, etc.?)
- Etc.

Yeah, Dawntrail's story sucked, and if you're the kind of player that reduces the whole MMO down to just its story then I can see Dawntrail being unredeemable, but that's simply not the case for me.

snippet.textDisplay:
I thought you were going to say Cataclysm.  Or Warlords of Draenor.  What people forget is that SL was supposed to be the redemption of BFA and it was not - that is why people were angry about Shadowlands, because of BFA.  The corruption system and Visions in BFA were a lot of fun though.
As for class locking transmogs?  I think it would be okay if they did it by job type - so melee could be locked to tank/melee dps and ranged could be lock to phys range and caster/heal.  The fact that we needed to have 4 different versions of a necklace or bracelet for transmogs was worse than having a chest piece class locked.  
I may go back to WoW if they really make it so people can't use addons for raiding.  I would often disable DBM just to see if I could figure things out on my own (and I typically could).

snippet.textDisplay:
Nice video, Mike. Appreciate your measured approach to this, always!

I'm happy for the WoW players that it's got back to a better place; I've toyed with it a few times and I don't think it's ever going to be for me, but I don't really want to try and squeeze a second MMO into my life anyway. Yet I'm super grateful for what the competition between them has done to improve both games.

I think I liked Dawntrail's story slightly more than the average person, but while it was a soft-handed restart narratively, the core combat encounters have just kept getting better. As someone who's more of a casual, story-focused player, I've kept coming back for weekly raids and such far longer than I ever did in past expansions. However the narrative pans out from here, I'm just as excited for the battle content it'll bring, and that feels really good. Plus seeing them actually step up and start throwing all this QoL stuff at us is good to see; it feels like the fire has been relit under them of late.
snippet.textOriginal:
Nice video, Mike. Appreciate your measured approach to this, always!

I'm happy for the WoW players that it's got back to a better place; I've toyed with it a few times and I don't think it's ever going to be for me, but I don't really want to try and squeeze a second MMO into my life anyway. Yet I'm super grateful for what the competition between them has done to improve both games.

I think I liked Dawntrail's story slightly more than the average person, but while it was a soft-handed restart narratively, the core combat encounters have just kept getting better. As someone who's more of a casual, story-focused player, I've kept coming back for weekly raids and such far longer than I ever did in past expansions. However the narrative pans out from here, I'm just as excited for the battle content it'll bring, and that feels really good. Plus seeing them actually step up and start throwing all this QoL stuff at us is good to see; it feels like the fire has been relit under them of late.

snippet.textDisplay:
The comparison between Dawntrail and Shadowlands is completely superficial because all people are really saying is, "this is the lowest point of the game that caused millions to quit the game." That's it.

More importantly, it sidelines genuine concerns that led us to the point of resentment and frustration that is currently exploding on the XIV side of things. Sure, Dawntrail's story was abysmal, but that isn't the main problem with Dawntrail. It was simply the last straw for the game.

You can find videos of XIV content creators and players complaining about the problems that XIV has that go as far back as a decade and STILL haven't been addressed.

Predatory housing system? Not addressed.
Abysmal friend's list? Not addressed.
Horrible alt job gearing system? Not addressed.
Terrible netcode that requires plugins to make the game playable? Not addressed.
Horrible antiquated UI? Not addressed.
Disastrous and convoluted glamour system? Not addressed.

The award-winning story was the one thing keeping the deluge of frustrations at bay, because we were all so immersed and invested that we looked past the blemishes XIV had. But now that people are no longer in love with the world, people have realized that these are not blemishes. They are massive, hairy warts.

As a WoW refugee during shadowlands that tried XIV and fell in love with the world, I could understand why Preach might see this a cyclical back and forth and now it's XIV's turn in this neverending cycle to respond to WoW's success. But the reality of the situation is, people are frustrated because CBU3 never responds. They acknowledge the problem in the live letters, apologize, then give vague plans to address it later down the line, then they never do.

To give you an idea of how bad it actually is, here's a fun fact most people might not know: The reason discord was created was because a disgruntled FFXIV player was so frustrated with the terrible chat/friend system in the game, they made their own program to circumvent CBU3's unwillingness to fix it. 

Yes, THE discord we have all been using for 9 years now. 
And CBU3 still has not improved the friend's list in any way, shape or form.

snippet.textDisplay:
Dawntrail is no better than Shadowlands; it's significantly worse.

1. The MSQ, which makes up the bulk of FFXIV, since that's where you invest most of your time, has been turned into absolute hell in DT thanks to people like Kate Cwynar and Sena Byrer. Wuk Lamat was such a poorly written character.
2. The same pattern repeats itself from expansion to expansion. There are no surprises.
3. The fact that gear will soon no longer be class-specific reminds me of the two-dye thing that was announced, and to me it's just a distraction so that CBU3 doesn't come across as uncreative.
4. Yoshi-P is completely past his prime, and you can sense that he doesn't really feel like doing it anymore.

snippet.textDisplay:
Saying Dawntrail is like BFA does not exactly make it better......I would say it is more like Cataclysm, a great stumble but nothing that cant be recovered from.

I would also say that Preach/Mike is not really qualified to talk about this since he has never really given a shit about WoW's lore and history until very recently. He didn't even know who Arthas was when wotlk came out. So I don't think he either understands or knows how devastating BFA was for people that loved WoW for its lore and story and had been following it since the Wacraft RTS days.  

BFA was the worst expansion in at that point World of Warcraft's 15 year old life time until Shadowlands came out and managed to top it even more. It was the GoT season 7/8 where the writers just rushed through several almost 10+ year built up story lines at a lightning pace in order to get all the "loose threads" out of the way so they could focus on "their own new original stories", storylines that could be entire expansions on their own reduced down to a single patch or instance. 

If Shadowlands destroyed/tainted WoW's lore foundation and what came before with all the retcons, then BFA destroyed Warcraft's future making all that came after it feel aimless and out of nowhere.

snippet.textDisplay:
I can enjoy both FFXIV and WoW, but there's one major difference. When I get tired of FFXIV, I take a break while still thinking positively about the game. But when I get tired of WoW, I loathe it for a while. I think this comes from most of WoW's content being either far too easy and unrewarding, or requiring more commitment than I can spare.

There's nothing in WoW like FFXIV's Extreme Trials or even Normal Raids. WoW's raids (on an engaging difficulty, leaving out LFR) take several hours, and break up due to slightest problems. Then there's Mythic+, which is shorter form, but often has hostile players (caused by how punishing failure is) and no clear end goal. What I like to play is something that's over after I've beaten it. WoW's easier content like Delves is anything but, they're endless treadmills of drip fed rewards that eventually feel to me like psychological manipulation in an attempt to make you addicted.

snippet.textDisplay: People will probably lynch me for this comment but here it goes. I play FF14 very casually and only play for the story. In Dawntrail I only played through main MSQ so far until the credits I haven't played any patch story yet but if I had to compare this to WoW's recent stories I'd say Dawntrail is much better than anything else WoW has put out in the past 5+ years. Yes sure Wuklamat is cringe as hell, but Bakul'jaja's backstory, and the whole Endless Storyline (the ghost city) made me cry several times. WoW's story made me cry last time in Legion when Ysera died and that side quest with Runas the Shamed.. that was what 8 years ago now? WoW's story feels too safe, it's all about family and coming and working together against a greater evil.. super boring and they don't take risks anymore.

snippet.textDisplay:
Perhaps it‚Äôs sample bias, but on the FF14 side, job design seems like the most obvious culprit that isn‚Äôt talked about as much in this video. Amongst new and old FCs, all my raiding groups I‚Äôve been in for the last 2 expansions, it has ALWAYS been the number 1 complaint. Jobs are MUCH simpler than Stormblood, and either simpler or almost identical to 5 years ago, yet significantly more powerful, with less costs/decisions to make.

Casual content got simpler in Endwalker, and had a small, but often irrelevant uptick in difficulty in Dawntrail (any amount of mistakes is trivialized by a healer pressing 1-2 of their free buttons, while healers are entirely superfluous unless multiple bad mistakes are made by the whole party in a row). That, on top of the stagnant job design, means so many of those players that came in around 2020 have been playing the exact same game for 5 years, and they got better while it got easier.

The end result is a lot of players who can‚Äôt find the engagement they used to have because they‚Äôve now mastered the simple jobs, and outgrown the difficulty of the casual content. Before, you could enjoy casual content as a good player because your job was engaging at a baseline. Now, when neither your class nor the content takes any attention anymore, do you really want to do your dailies? This has been the story of almost everyone I know that has quit or taken a break in the last few years. When you add that to DT‚Äôs story‚Äôs reception, two main pillars of the game, battle content and story, failing to capture so much of their once-audience, it makes sense player count is reaching Stormblood levels again.

The end result is a lot of players who can‚Äôt find the engagement they used to have because they‚Äôve now mastered the simple jobs, and outgrown the difficulty of the casual content. snippet.textDisplay:
Shadowlands i left because systems were just unfun and forced, FF14 currently isnt horrible but isnt good either. I still can see myself playing again for the story and i will say i do like how in FF14 i can feel finished and do something else. It was alot easier for me to walk away from FF14 than it was for WoW.

 Anyways my main gripe with FF14 is the players more than the systems, to me the systems need some tweaking and improvements but the players is where its kind of rough. In my 4 years of playing FF14, I have dealt with soooo much drama than in my 15yrs of WoW. People say WoW's playerbase is toxic, thats mainly true if you just pug and even that all theyll do is talk shit to you in one moment and then youll never see that player again most likely. In Guilds 90% of the time everyone is on the same page and are pretty welcoming and helpful. FF14 on the other hand you join an FC and things go good for a little while until you rub someone the wrong way especially unintentionally. Say you and an FC mate are talking in discord and you mention something beliefs wise whether it be world views, political views, FF14 opinions, and someone whos not even part of the conversation sees or hears it that doesnt agree with those things, they now label you a very hateful person and everyone needs to know about it. However this person or persons have a problem with you for wrongthink and instead of being adults and talking to you about it for clarification or even just a simple "hey i overheard you say x and it made me feel off, what did you mean?" they start rumors about you or act like theyre your best friend while speaking hate about you behind your back to make everyone hate you too like we're in highschool still. 

In the same breath there are alot of sad lonely ppl in FF14 who attatch themselves to other players mostly female players in roleplay settings and get very possessive of them and start drama over it to the point where they stalk players in game. Ive even seen FCs stalk players they kick or if an FC split happens they like to harass ppl on the other end of the split. Ive even see RP clubbing tear Fcs apart because if you dont RP or in my experience Mod the game, you are treated as if you dont exist. I tried clubbing and had alot of friends but as soon as i started raiding in 14 i lost all my friends because I didnt club anymore. I even lost a friend to modding, we used to play everyday and chill but as soon as they got into modding its like i didnt exist anymore because i didnt like modding and theyd rather play with other modders.

Then finally the raiding community. The thing that got me about the raid community is statics dont stay together, everyone is more worried about their own progression than helping the team. We start off as a team but then some discover they are more skilled at raiding than others and are unwilling to help with progressing as a team and start going into PF to push their progress despite it gimping the main team if they clear before raid days. All the teams i was apart of you always had 2 or 3 players clearing at reset then screwing us over with loot because they got their kill already and or eventually just left the team or no showed because they can clear without the team. This is the reason i liked wows system better because ppl can help and not screw over the loot.

snippet.textDisplay:
The problem is that XIV just has become extremely stale. They seem absolutely hell bent on keeping to how they've always done things, every single expansion and patch is entirely predictable in what it brings years ahead.
Seemingly benign features that are important to people are taking them literal years to implement. Unless they can massively innovate on their core gameplay, content structure, gear system and reward structures in the next expansion... well, things aren't looking well right now. The latest census is showing a roughly 50% decline in active player numbers compared to the game's peak around 3 years ago and  with no signs of slowing down. They need to change things, and fast. Both aren't exactly points they've excelled at in the past, so I'm rather skeptical that this will come to pass. Where Yoshi-P'S leadership once seemed like a boon for the game, his stubbornness to change now seems to hold the game back from becoming more than what it's started off as 12 years ago.

That being said, those systems aren‚Äôt terrible, they need refinement, polish, and updating. snippet.textDisplay: And I don't know if you just don't remember WoD and maybe you weren't a current player, but WoD was a much worse expansion than SL. Shadowlands was bad, but WoD was worse. The first 'patch' we got was just a camera. We have a 14 month gap between the release of WoD and an actual patch with decent amounts of content. Let's not forget the at least two patches of things that was cut. The capitol cities that were cut. And the ending of WoD completely changing from what was told to us. So yeah Shadowlands is in the bottom, but it is far from the worse. Most of the SL pains were felt inflicted pains caused by the player themselves who felt as if they had to do everything at once.

snippet.textDisplay:
Ill be honest, making a video saying some minor adjustments to features that players have been begging SE to do for the better part of a decade, without addressing any of the core issues that exist somehow represents marked competition and innovation in FF14 is a wild take.

People didnt just leave the gane because DT BAD, they left because the game has had the same issues, with constant promises to fix them or outright refusal to acknowledge them as problems, given somewhat of a pass by the community because the game had a story everyone loved.
Like bethesda, the good will and solid writing are long gone now though. 

Comparing the veil of FF14's story ending and revealing just how little the game has meaningfully improved since ARR to WoW still having class locked cosmetics (despite it getting a massively better glam system anyway) reads like genuine cope at worst and being out of touch with why people have grown tired of the game at best.

People genuinely forget how bad Shadowlands was, especially on the story front. It was bottom of the barrel writting that tried to freaking slip in bootleg Thanos at the last minute and retroactively ruined multiple legacy characters

Sylvannas went from being one of the most interesting Warcraft characters with countless threads and fan theories about her potential fate & arc, to easily the most hated and I feel that alone says a LOT.

Dawntrail is literally *not even close* to being that bad, it doesn't touch the ARR - Endwalker saga at all. Its basically a glorified filler arc that leads into the real plot, one that could have been written far better, but its not as bad as people make it out to be.

snippet.textDisplay:
I never held you to really judge ff14 since you came so late to the game and experiencing it fresh. A lot of the frustrations have been more pent up over the years for final fantasy with weak systems and something that's interesting in theory but doesn't work or just bad but gets SLIGHTLY better by the end of it so it's easier for people to go back and experience. Bozja, eureka etc are examples of it being largely different experiences from launch of content to someone going back and experiencing it as a fresh player or just most other content.

 It's a frustration that barely anything has lasted or evergreen content  for the most part in ff14s life. Or had such minimal changes for QoL and gearing seeing only a reduction rather than an enhancement. For the most part, it's a blip of something you do for a SHORT period but then never touch. For awhile it was touch and go with the lack of deep dungeon stuff for example and half attempts at that or content similar.

 For a lot of people, with the lack of SOLID new fresh things that stuck around that people could do for awhile especially PVE content wise that had a reason for you to do it, the remaining glue holding them to the game was the story. With that being mediocre, there was just little reason. It's not even just "well the story feels concluded now" it's more "I just don't care about this arc" a good example would be from wotlk to cataclysm. Even down to green jesus. Where the story felt "finished" with the lich king but now here's a new thing and they did a lot of fresh elements with it. The systems for cata weren't great same with the tuning here and there and the final raid but it wasn't an absolutely bad xpac all over. Just weaker and ruined the old world. 

Some may say WoW just copies ff14 but WoW has also tried and failed many things on the PVE front that FF14 fails to deliver on and copies WoW with. So it goes both ways when copying.  I miss when the world told its story and you see many people going around with some of the characters sprinkled in over the ff14 approach that WoW has pushed off and on since cata. But they are going full "band of friends" as of late.

(I was ok with disabling powerful combat addons like weakauras, but they crossed my line and also disbaled unit frame addons and made it impossible to alter the default UI - yeah I'm not supporting a company that pulls the rug out from under players while lying about it.) FF14 is still up in the air for me.  I gradually drifted away from the game after Endwalker (which was fantastic until the lackluster patch content).  If they improve FF14 again I'll consider playing it again (a Switch 2 version would make it more likely for me).

FF14 is still up in the air for me.  I gradually drifted away from the game after Endwalker (which was fantastic until the lackluster patch content).  If they improve FF14 again I'll consider playing it again (a Switch 2 version would make it more likely for me).

snippet.textOriginal: Anybody who thinks dawntrail is the shadowlands of FF14 were NOT THERE for shadowlands.

snippet.textDisplay:
Dawntrail was so bad and I became so utterly disheartened by the game that I wrote a scathing review on it and the only other game I did this for was Helldivers during the PSN fiasco - I would've done one for Shadowlands too, but Blizzard doesn't give me that chance. A lot of people speak of Dawntrail's story as its defining low. It's not - it really isn't. The game would be good if the Story was its lowest point because, as bad as it is, it isn't THAT bad. A game is a game and a game is defined by all of it as a whole and for something like an MMO, that is meant to be a game you SUB to and play continuously, gameplay is king.

Honestly, the review expresses my view on it in such length that I can't through youtube comments without upsetting people, but here's the most glaring excerpt IMO and it'll probably determine the MMOs future.

Content cadence has become slower than EW, which had already slowed slightly from ShB to a point that is actually grueling. 6+ months for a 4-boss savage is laughable. At the very least, in this latest odd patch, they actually added something to stimy the time between savages with the new 4-man 'savage' fight. Not that it has good rewards, mind you, a recurring theme, really.

Circling back to the point of gameplay. The 2-minute meta has become well estblished after its inception in ShB. With the repeated trimming of jobs, the uniformization of job gameplay and everything else, the reality of this game's gameplay has come to the forefront. As one of the two premiere tab-targetting MMOs, comparisons with WoW are abound and the truth of the matter is simple. If you want an interesting MMO with interesting combat that doesn't have too high of a skill floor, you need either trimmed down gameplay that's fast or complex/busy gameplay that's slow. XIV had the latter, but are moving towards the former. In this limbo state, the game presents itself as a game with slow gameplay and trimmed down jobs - in short, it presents itself as repetetitve and dull in its core gameplay loop with Jobs that are very samey and seldom have much to separate them bar job identity.
